As an immigrant’s kid, I deeply appreciated how this film didn’t shy away from the messy parts of life away from one’s home country—the ugly parts of choosing to be displaced for some years in hopes of saving enough to build a better life for OTHERS who might not even deserve it
I liked the subtle commentaries
Life is unfair
It also didn’t present perfect characters, which is rare for a Filipino mainstream romance movie
This one had messy people
No hints of self-righteousness
And you can’t help but root for them because of that
I love films that do this
Remind you of the cheesiness and beauty of being human
Of falling in love, of owning pain, of being honest about hurting, of independence and codependency, of giving and dreaming

Hello, Love, Goodbye starts with Joy (played by Kathryn Bernardo) saying something like, ¨In Hongkong we don´t waste time because every second counts and every second we are payed¨

The film works best when it follows this premise- when Joy acts as the ´kayod lang ng kayod´ breadwinner of the family and when she desperately searches for ways to support her dream of flying to Canada to seek a job and follow her passion
However, when Ethan (played by Alden Richards) comes into the picture, this premise suddenly shatters, bringing back the movie to its commercial origin
A DIFFERENT CATHY GARCIA-MOLINA FILMThis film is envisioned to be like one of the remarkable classic OFW films in the past like ´Dubai´, and ´Milan´
Fortunately, the film doesn´t settle for that vision alone
It raises the story, nuanced to experiences by domestic helpers based in Hong Kong, where it is illegal to take another job aside from being a DH
It also digs deeper, creating a more compelling and informative story about the overseas Filipino workers in Hong Kong
To this end, the film may be given credit for its thorough research

THE MIDDLE STUMBLESIt could have been great if the film lived up to that premise and made that nuanced Hong Kong experience as it`s core, but instead it uses the romantic narrative as a way to effectively communicate with its audience
It is here, in the halfway of the movie, where it fails to function as a compelling narrative piece
Just when Ethan comes into the picture, familiar Filipino movie production processes and cliches come into play

Take for example the Wattpad-ish treatment of Ethan´s character, the way he is perceived as a playboy and later on revealed that he´s not so bad after all because of previous traumas he had encountered, the cringey mix of English and Tagalog to try to create remarkable lines, inserting some product brands into the movie that never really contributes to the story, using some irrelevant sequences and drone shots that make the film look weird and the quality subpar, and most importantly the redundant score that´s being played using different instruments to create a grandiose melodrama just like every Cathy Garcia-Molina film
Truth be told, there´s really nothing that is compelling in the film´s second part
It all looks like a really long pantomime with ¨Kung ´Di Rin Lang Ikaw¨ as background
THE SLIGHT RESURRECTIONThankfully, all the second part craze undos itself in the film´s last few minutes
Here, the struggles of both Joy and Ethan are discussed and are powerfully put together to give the film a compelling touch, grounded to the themes presented in the film´s opening
The last few minutes of the film however still feels like a long music video
Only this time, it´s disguised as a travelogue
Although, it is in this long sequence where the most delightful shots are shown, it kind of feels just like a long compilation of tourist vlogs rather than an essential part of the story
Another resurrection comes at the film´s last minute
It brilliantly presents the resolution, bringing it to a powerful last shot reminiscent to that of Alfonso Cuaron´s `Roma´, but more explicitly told
THE BEST OF KATHRYNI never thought I would say this, but this is definitely Kathryn´s film
Though this is her most daring and demanding role yet, she perfectly portrays Joy´s desperation, desire, and inherent sadness
This performance is her all-time best and I can, with no doubt say that it is something that should seriously be considered by the country´s award-giving bodies
Alden Richard´s Ethan however feels like a character that was written for Kathryn´s on-screen partner, Daniel Padilla
Despite this, Alden Richards still plays the role with heart
Unlike Kathryn´s role, Ethan is not a dramatically demanding character
This is somehow opposite to Richards´ past roles which never fails to use tears and eye acting as tools for storytelling
In the end, it feels like Alden is only a supporting character in this movie
INCONSISTENTLY GOODSometimes, Hello, Love, Goodbye struggles to cope up with it´s promising premise
At one point it proudly flaunts it´s technical excellence, and the next thing you see, a drone is randomly used to show a scene where the main characters are running on a rooftop
Sometimes it also shines as a narrative piece while the next second, it reeks of shit
This film has a lot of potential, in all honesty

However, it does not consistently makes use of that potential, and most of the time it acts like one of those commercial films in the market- settles for the mediocre, and the audience appeal while sacrificing good storytelling
Despite this, it still should be regarded as a cinematic achievement as it presents a raw aspect of the difficult life abroad despite being a studio-made film
Cathy Garcia-Molina has revitalized her storytelling voice
A good mix of crowd-pleasing moments and hard-to-swallow truths
The film didn’t pull any punches
It left me gushing and gut-wrenched at the same time
Isang ehemplo ang "Hello, Love, Goodbye" na pedeng tibagin ang mga nakasanayan na nating tambalan, ipares sa iba pang tao, at pede pa ring makaramdam ng saya at kilig habang pinapanood sila
May kakaibang timpla ang tambalang Alden at Kathryn na hindi nakakasawang panuorin

Never have I ever watched a Filipino movie with the same typical couple until this came out, and this is one of the reasons why it was extraordinary

They had definitely given the audience another chemistry and vibe to maybe spice things up and break that notion of having the same couple on screen; however, what really made this movie so good is its plot
Every bit of its scene mirrors the reality of life and through that, true love is depicted in the story
You may bump into some cheesy and corny lines, but you could quite see how the two leads were able to emulate the vibes of Filipinos
If you're not into romantic type of movies, don't worry
You can still relate to it in some other perspective
Love can also be expressed in a platonic way
:) So, this is definitely a must watch

Hello, Love, Goodbye is a film I didn't expect to like
I went to the cinema with a passive indifference to pass the time, yet I was utterly blown away once the opening montage scene started
It reminded me of the claustrophobic isolation and weariness of Chungking Express, which also took place in Hong Kong
I thought to myself that it wasn't a bad start at all and it piqued my interest, hoping it manages to be consistently good throughout
And it did
The portrayal of domestic helpers is realistic
It doesn't go all the way to make it a tragic story, to the point of being depressing, as it manages to be hopeful at times with frequent lighthearted moments
I have a soft spot for stories about OFW struggles
Being a child of an OFW, I've witnessed various injustices prevalent in the OFW community
The movie brings to light several of them, and they hit home
Surprisingly, I didn't find the romance corny at all
Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards both come from different well-established love teams, and I was initially skeptical that a chemistry between them wouldn't work
However, they manage to exceed expectations as they bring the best out of each other
Kathryn portrayed the role of Joy convincingly as a struggling domestic helper trying to make ends meet and realize her dreams
Alden portrayed the role of Ethan as your typical playboy, but he manages to bring out enough nuance to an honestly flawed character escaping the ghosts of his past
The cinematography is decent, providing enough satisfactory camera angles to capture the scenic Hong Kong backdrop
The script is pretty standard for a Cathy Garcia-Molina film but sufficiently witty, sappy, and genuine all at once
The score is average but serviceable
Certain scenes could've had more emotional impact and tension without the dramatic music
The acting of some minor characters needs improvement
Despite that, it's not distracting when you have two lead characters pouring their heart out in their respective roles
To conclude, Hello, Love, Goodbye isn't just a typical straightforward romance film for me
It had enough going on in its story to be engaging while being paced well enough
The chemistry is there, and I must admit that the movie touched me in a way that other of its contemporaries haven't
Ultimately what resonated with me most in this particular film is how it addresses love in the most honest and vulnerable way possible
Every subplot is instrumental and significant to the film's conclusion, making a brutal yet optimistic statement that I rarely see in romance stories in general

Beyond the romance blossoming between the two leads, this shows the hardships and difficulties of life while living as an OFW (Oversees Filipino Worker) - the limited choices and the sacrifices the characters have to endure
Kathryn Bernardo gives a stellar performance as Joy - and this is possibly her best performance to date
She is clearly supported by her male co-star who reciprocates her performance though Bernardo is the center of the story
My primary issue with Filipino romance films is the direction the romance will take when the leads are faced with a dilemma
Usually it’s the woman who ends up self-sacrificing for love, or the issues of the man are not addressed while giving the couple their happy ending
Sometimes the ending could be a cop-out, instead of letting it naturally play out
This played out perfectly - it was sensible and realistic
There was no gimmick, and the direction their relationship headed addressed the situation the leads were in
This is one for the books
Also kudos to the cinematographer and the writer
Kathryn's performance here was quintessential Kathryn, Kathryn on The Hows of Us was really the best I have seen from her

The way the film presented his character and how we got to know him better was very effective
(May I just note that Joross Gamboa's performance here was so hilarious

Like, as in sobrang benta ng jokes na kahit ano nalang din siguro lumabas sa bibig niya ay nakakatawa rito)Story wise, what I really did like was it didn't romanticize the hardships of our OFWs, it presented the harsh reality of working outside the country
Kathryn really captured it
The film wasn't really the dark, heavy drama-ish film but it made me reflect on the privileges that I have and shouldn't take for granted
Last note, sana mapalitan 'yung chroma part sa last scene choz

So so so film
A young Filipino woman working in Hong Kong meets a young bartender
She's about to complete her contract and go to greener pastures in Canada
Normally, I wouldn't go for this type of film
And it's by Cathy Garcia-Molina, so seeing her name normally makes me go to the opposite direction, having seen a few of her past films
But this one, to her credit, has a bit more substance
There's a compelling drama here about the plight of Overseas Filipino Workers (OFW's) but blended with the formulaic romantic-dramedy that is her bread and butter
They do the usual "hugot" emotional romantic scene in the end where they telegraph every emotion through overly written emotional speeches each trying to out-romance each other
But it's still a solid drama before that

If there's one thing the movie can really boast about, it's the strength of the acting between its two leads
Kathryn Bernardo acted her heart out in this
You can literally feel the sweat, desperation and exhaustion her character endures in her stint as a domestic helper in Hong Kong
At this point, she proved that she can carry a movie all by herself
Alden Richards also proved here that he came a long way from his pabebe Aldub days
His acting definitely improved and was pretty solid overall
Although I did have a problem with how the relationship started in the first half (Alden really was a straight up stalker, wasn't he

), the movie redeemed itself after, not just with how the relationship was ultimately executed, but the execution of the film's central message of how loving yourself over everything else is not necessarily a selfish thing
There's definite chemistry between the two of them, and given how successful the movie is critically and financially speaking, I'm looking forward to their next movie together
Another thing that I really like is that (without getting into spoilers) the movie could had easily ended in a traditional happy ending
They could had easily added a certain scene in the end to do that
But they chose not to, instead delving more into an ending that is whilst bittersweet, much more grounded and admirable
It made the movie had so much more of an impact at the end (and I already really dug the last ten minutes so that was something)
Hopefully Star Cinema does keep up this surge of quality and care in its films
I mean, it's not a stunning innovation per se, but it's a noticeable improvement in quality (*coughs* Vice Ganda *coughs*)

If there's one thing to be learned from this movie, it's that Filipino audiences do are starting to care on the quality of their local mainstream films, and less on cheap laughs and hollow kilig moments

Hello, Love, Goodbye (Review)CGM's farewell note to cinema is a sincere procedural on the measures of familial, eros and self love
Chungking Express and Before Sunrise, anyone
I kid
This time, blockbuster director CGM challenged herself, or at least that's what I felt and saw
Apart from the word play and tongue in cheek banters we've all grown accustomed to most of her films, this one hits different
And looks different as welk
From the trailing shots, the hallucinogenic montages and moody shots Ala WKW, this really is quite the departure from the usual Cathy Garcia Molina

And I commend her for that, and obviously giving due props to her (presumably) auteur aspirations, WKW and Linklater, Hello, Love, Goodbye served us feel good familiarity and a bit of philosophy on the power of choice and chance
Damang dama ko yung pagod ni Joy bilang ofw na walang sawa sa pag suporta sa pamilya niya

Sakripisyo talaga, selflessness at lakas ng loob ang puhunan
Napaka importante rin talaga na piliin mo muna sarili mo dahil kung hindi, you will lose yourself along the way
Ang hirap
Kaya para sa mga taong inuna ang pamilya bago ang sarili, tangina, saludo

The two main actors for this film are big stars and are part of the two most popular tandems in the Philippines (with different partners, though) so I thought this was going to be another teeny-bopper-lovey-dovey movie but I still gave it a go since this newly-formed loveteam intrigued me
I normally am not a big fan of romances but I was so pleasantly surprised by this movie
The marketing was mostly focusing on the love story (because Filipinos usually…
By far, the best Cathy Garcia-Molina movie in my opinion
Surprisingly, Kathryn and Alden definitely have a chemistry, even if they were in different TV stations
CGM really squeezed these two leads to their boundaries to deliver an outstanding movie that is well loved by the fans, the non-fans and the critics
It's not that over-the-top drama but the supporting actors really did all of that
It's a signature CGM move
The supportive, loud, hilarious friends can be quite an eye and ear sore
I know, it is to balance all the drama and stuff but does it really have to be OA (over-acting)
The realism of the story is the selling point of this one aside from the lead actors
And it's perfectly portrayed and captured
You can feel the hardships, the pain, with or without experiencing it, it will hit you very hard
A sequel may or may not be needed
But I'm very satisfied on how it ended
Change is good
And we need more movies like this

I'll be the first to admit that I dismiss Kathryn as an actress simply because:(1) she is half of the Kathniel love team and I just find them so cliche and the typical Pinoy media play just doesn't do it for me anymore(2) I gave her (and Daniel) a chance went I watched The Hows of Us with friends last year and I spent the whole time cringing and regretting my decision to be there(3) I prefer JaDine because I feel they are more genuine and, basically, just more real (I don't dismiss the entire Filipino entertainment industry, fyi)Got dragged into this with friends
I had low expectations given my last movie experience with Kathryn, but I gave it a chance because Daniel wasn't in it and I thought maybe it would be a little better somehow
I like Alden, but I didn't really know how his acting chops were

I was pleasantly surprised by how the film turned out - the plot was honestly a bit predictable but it generally somehow felt more real and refreshing than other Filipino rom-coms (I appreciate this very much, given the number of stereotype Filipino films coming out in the last x years)
Alden was great, and I look forward to his next projects
I'm sure he'll get more offers after this
His pairing with Kathryn, I'm sure, has done wonders for his career since this came out
I still think she has a lot of growth maturing to do in terms of her acting (my preference, at least), but seeing this film really changed my opinion of her (at least half of it, I suppose)
Definitely still prefer JaDine, and definitely won't be voluntarily watching out for whatever she does next, but she has one less hater in me

saw this latest star cinema drama and i wish i could say i loved it

true, it’s a marked improvement from the typical rom-coms the studio is famous for but still, despite its spotlight on a subculture of filipino expatriates living as quasi-citizens/residents of hongkong, it is still saddled by the usual storytelling cliches and harrowing contrivances that makes the film less involving and feels a tad bit manufactured

the movie tells the story of ethan and joy who meets in hongkong at a wrong time in their lives — she is trying to get away from hongkong and live her dream in canada while he is trying to reestablish his roots and his relationship with his family in the island after a failed relationship in the US

it’s a good setup but it was not unfortunately sustained when the narrative decided to give more time on cutesy scenes featuring the usual go-to “best friends” that may be permanently engraved at every screenplay that’s greenlit by star cinema bosses

and i observed one very sad thing about the movie: i understand that the intention is good but this movie seems to be telling us that families, at least in the vision of the filmmakers, are the modern-day representation of “talangka filipino mentality” — in this movie, they seem to get, however unintended, in the way of the dreams, ambitions and happiness of the main protagonists even if the portrayal depicts the age-old child sacrificing all for family
disclosure: i saw the brilliant film “the farewell” one day before this film and i may have been unfairly influenced by it into expecting that all films could be just as good
this movie was a quick wake-up call that not all movies are good no matter how well-intentioned they are
This is a "I want to have a jowa after this movie" type of film

Very formulaic and nothing new from what you've seen from Star Cinema, however, Alden and Kathryn have such great chemistry that they make it work more than it should
Their acting is great even if its surrounded by a pretty cliche storyline
HELLO, LOVE, GOODBYE REVIEW Hello, Love, Goodbye is a film about a domestic helper in Hong Kong; her name is Joy (Kathryn Bernardo)

In her last four months in Hong Kong, she met a guy named Ethan (Alden Richards) and at first, she is making him go away because she is finding money for the paper works to be submitted to the Canadian Embassy and not a friend or a relationship
But Ethan persevered and Joy falls in love with him
In this film, we can see the conflict in choosing between love or dream, their own conflicts as a character and the hard work and sacrifice of an OFW (Overseas Filipino Worker)
First of all, why are there many films coming out in the Philippines about adult rom com
I don’t know why but all of them is a box office hit
It is well and good that they showed the harsh reality of the life of an OFW; as a family of an OFW, it is sad for us
They are doing the best that they can, but they are still mistreated by their landlords
As big as forgetting to fetch their children at school to as little as forgetting to take the trash out
There are a lot of stories happening at once, but they resolved everything at the end
These stories are a gateway to show the main characters’ internal conflict not just between them
COMEDY IS ON POINT
Just as expected with Joross Gamboa
Not too many and not too few, just the right amount of spice
Also, there are too many cliché moments, but it worked out well without me cringing
This is one of the Filipino’s illness when it comes to films; they are too afraid of just letting the visual tell the story
Lines are too much; they somewhat gave away the story before the climax
They did not let the audience think instead they laid it all out for us
I hope that they overcome this fear and let the visual tell the story
I’m also glad that they used the original artist’s songs and not just cover it
It sets the mood rather than someone covering it
Lastly, cinematography is meh, okay but I can forgive this one because they shot this entirely in Hong Kong with some parts here in the Philippines
Overall, I give this film a 7/10
Film can be improved by deducting some parts, cut down their lines in half and let the visuals tell the story
Although, acting is on point, I think Star Cinema can squeeze more out of Alden Richards
Cinematography can also be improved by using tripods, stabilizers and a professional drone operator (some aerial shots are jittery)
This is your typical “love, dream and family” story but they added the hardships of being an OFW

It's a story about hope, sacrifice, and ultimately finding that little ray of sunshine that can make it all bearable

What I really like about HLG is that as it goes along it feels riveting on a simplistic scale, it becomes expressive of our own feelings
The theme is on the idea of love (almost didn’t work for me), but the direction pulls in the audience through its characters— I am every bit of Ethan and Joy
I work overseas but I have so much to be thankful for that I am not a breadwinner, no responsibilities aside from myself and I have a job that I wanted for myself
Movies are indeed powerful
This made me more appreciative of the life I have now— it’s good and a privilege, therefore I should not take it for granted

It is a feeling of mixed emotions watching the movie
Once again, we are reminded of the diaspora of Filipinos or OFW's to well off countries such as Hongkong and Canada to look for better paying jobs, no matter what these jobs are
It is sad because of the extreme difficulties encountered by the OFW's
At the same time, I feel thankful that there are jobs and income to support the families back home
Joy's work in Hongkong is hard - her pay is reduced, she gets a part-time job and runs from the Hongkong police because of it
In the middle of this, she sends home money to the Philippines and finds a friend, Ethan
Happiness finds its own source and with Joy, it is in the Central Park where all the "kababayans" provide comfort to one another in the middle of a foreign country with an alienating culture
It is also in Ethan whom she fell in love with
The movie is well directed and masterfully portrays the lives of domestic helpers
Salute to Cathy Garcia-Molina
The script is tight and romantic which clicks with the Filipino audience: "when you talk to strangers, there is no judgement" and " I love you" (witty remark to mean stay away)
Finally, Kathryn Bernardo acts very well, she is the next Bea Alonzo
As for Alden Richards, with his handsome face, he can go places in the film industry
Walangya, ang ganda

now, this might seem utterly ridiculous, for me to call this film a “Masterpiece”—and of course, it really isn’t—but man do all the positives about this film outshine the very small qualms I have about this surprsing, genuine, and heartfelt Filipino romance

I really don’t know if it’s because I was only very slightly intoxicated, or because I’m a 20 year old gay Filipino in a wonderful relationship with my oh so sweet and loving Brazilian boyfriend, or the chemistry of Alden and Kathryn, or the admittedly cheesy but so emotionally-charged well-weitten dialogue, but this film
this film has made me cry more than any other film I’ve ever seen
More than my ultimate favorites, Lord of the Rings, Cloud Atlas, Spirited Away, Cinema Paradiso, Boy and the World
I literally had to turn away from the screen and bawl on my boyfriend’s shoulder in the cinema when that last conversation in the pier between Ethan and Joy
I really don’t know why this film struck me so hard
Maybe it’s all of the reasons I’ve lifted above
Or maybe this film is also just alright if I revisit it in a while
but wow, I really did not expect this reaction out of me going into this at all
By all means it is definitely not a more technically outstanding film than any of my other favorites, but man I’d be lying if I said this film didn’t touch me to my core
What a solid, beautiful film from Cathy

I’m glad this film exists

"Aldubyou""I do note
Alden Richards’ character, Ethan, is pushy, creepy and problematic
He will continue sending friend requests even if Joy declined several times already
He will make the radio station talk about Joy in public without her permission
He will use another phone to text Joy anonymously
He will act like a police even if Joy is weeping out of fear
He will squeeze through inside a small room knowing that Joy will be uncomfortable
He will continually send “Need a friend today
” text messages even if Joy has rejected it so many times
I don’t know how a Filipino girl reacts to such moves, but if people consider this as “nakakakilig,” there’s a problem
It almost gave me the same queasy feeling of the stalking problems I saw in Kita Kita and the French film Amélie
Hello, Love, Goodbye is at its best when it tells the story of Kathryn Bernardo’s character, Joy
In some ways, the film manages to outdo similar mainstream Filipino romance films because of Kathryn Bernardo’s stunning performance and the earnest depiction of OFWs (Overseas Filipino Workers)
Bernardo, whose acting holds the film together when it was falling apart, effectively evokes a palpable sense of weariness, discontent, and eagerness to alleviate Joy’s situation
Actually, I can do without the La La Land love story if the social commentary was strengthened and expounded more
In a similar vein with Sunday Beauty Queen, the film resonates with Filipinos because of its sensible portrayal of what it is like to work abroad in a job you are overqualified in

But Cathy Garcia-Molina’s picture falls apart as the annoying, melodramatic score continues to play in the background, tackier drone shots are added, and more forced, “hugot” dialogues are delivered by the leads
Sure, this is how cliché-ridden mainstream Filipino romance plays out
But how I wish we get movies that transcend this generic romantic stratagem
Hello, Love, Goodbye fails to offer something new to romance movies as an art form, and it is disappointing since the OFW story and Joy’s arc have so much potential
Filipino romcoms just can’t shy away with all the cheesiness but as a soon-to-be OFW I feel like I related to Kathryn’s Joy too much in a way that I HAVE to chase this dream
It’s all or nothing
And as my departure draws closer, there are moments when I suddenly become scared and I begin to question all my plans
So this movie really spoke to me in that aspect
takot lang din siguro akong mapag-iwanan
Your typical “troubled boy falls for a bright young girl”-themed romance— “A Walk to Remember” a
“Grease” a
“Say Anything”— Cathy Garcia Molina’s “Hello Love, Goodbye” discovers puppy love in its purest form
It has plot and spiels topped with cheddar, mozzarella, parmesan, cottage, and blue cheese
Pairing Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards is a genius move
This film showcased how good actor each of them is
Of course, we do not forget the supporting cast because they added extra entertainment and drama
The movie never failed to give a sense of claustrophobic feeling of alienation and loneliness in a developed world— the very reason why I think portrayal of Maymay’s character was so realistic
It is a good movie with great acting, average screenplay, and story topped with layers of clichés from the romantic drama genre
MY TWITTER REVIEW:The love story of Hello, Love, Goodbye (2019) couldn’t be more formulaic, although I won’t dismiss its sad factor, but I really couldn’t care less for it after the movie ended
What the movie successfully conveys is the sacrifices people make to have a better life,
to make ends meet, even if it means being away from the people you love
The family aspect of the movie really got me, it’s the subplot that actually made me cry
The plight of OFW’s in this film was executed very well—sensitively, with a lot of heart
It made a good depiction of how families want to be together but can’t, the pain and consequences of being away from them, dreams that have to be put on hold and the resilience of OFWs
I loved the movie because of that aspect
Again, as to the love story, not so much
MY FACEBOOK REVIEW:I have to admit that the love story of Hello, Love, Goodbye (2019) didn’t charm my socks off
It couldn’t be more formulaic and to be quite honest, it bored me
(Please don’t attack me )What I loved about it though, and where the film actually succeeds, is its depiction of the life of Overseas Filipino Workers (OFW)
It was executed very well—grounded, sensitive, full of heart
It showed how resilient Filipinos are and how we find humor in everything
That in any way that we can, we always find/create families when we’re away from our own
The film conveys how sacrifice can be selfless and also selfish
Selfless in the aspect of going away from your loved ones and braving a new world alone to make ends meet and eventually have a better quality of life
Also, that sacrifice can also be selfish, but not the bad kind (
I hope you get it), when it comes to choosing yourself, choosing your dreams instead of always trying to make the people around you happy

The values of this film resonates, especially in every OFW family, how families always try their best to be together albeit it might not actually happen or whenever it does, it’s going to be a long, long time
That in the end, and this might sound corny, love transcends loneliness, fear or hardship
My favorite scene would be when Kathryn, Kakay and their other friend were watching Vilma Santos’ iconic speech in ‘Anak’ and Kakay sobbingly asks, “Ang pagmamahal ba sa sakripisyo lang naipapakita
” It’s a good question, and my answer is NO

Sacrifices are not requirements in love; we don’t have to sacrifice anything just to show someone we love them but we do it because that’s how we try to make it work with someone we love and it’s necessary

For the first time I watched a Kathryn Bernardo movie in the cinema, since I'm not a fan, and I must say it did not disappoint me
The movie is a great depiction of the OFWs in Hong Kong, particularly the domestic helpers, through a romance film
Bernardo did great in this movie playing a domestic helper named Joy
Her character was well developed and mature and Bernardo was able to fully portray it with finesse

As you watch the movie and Joy's development you'd feel like you're watching the true pains and hardship that our fellow domestic helpers go through with their work and life in Hong Kong which I think is when the movie is at it's best
As for the romance part of the movie I did enjoy the on screen chemistry of the two leads and how they went through although their story is not as strong as Joy's personal story alone

Richards is fine as the opposite of Bernardo although I do cringe whenever he needs to deliver the cheesy taglish lines which I really don't like in most Cathy Garcia-Molina movies especially that the way those lines was written in the script, it's just that it did not matched with Richard's character Ethan

Overall I did really enjoy this movie from start until the end even though there were some low parts of the movie you can overlook those and find the movie enjoyable and will be happy to recommend it to anyone to see

"Hello, Love, Goodbye" is another landmark on Cathy Garcia-Molina's illustrious filmography
While it may not be her best movie, she sprays her piece with hints of realism, grit and realities on the backdrop of being a overseas worker
All the while, she brought it with some weight and optimism that makes it stand out from her recent movies, even though the tone seems derivative from them
It all works because of the performances of Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards, who are able to carry the levity of their down-to-earth characters
And their chemistry is surprisingly exquisite and wonderfully executed that their solution pays it off
The rest of the movie is filled with neat cinematography, a good pace and a cinematic feeling
And even if the rest of the cast fall on the usual entrapped cliches, it is Bernardo and Richards' rapport that makes "Hello, Love, Goodbye" transcend to its audience
It is one of those Filipino romance movies where I do not hear an over-the-top shouting match
That is at least an achievement

Cathy-Grace Molina is a definite veteran of the Filipino romance genre, and with Hello, Love, Goodbye, she might have just crafted her most culturally relevant, self-aware, and individually contemplative piece yet

At the very least, it is an authentic portrayal of the plight of the OFWs; But if it weren’t for the well-written, organic romance between the two lead characters, played endearingly well by both Alden Richards and Kathryn Bernardo, and with bountiful chemistry to spare, Goodbye may have fallen into the territory of clichéd conventional Filipino love story
Instead, it is a grounded romance elevated by heart, integrity, and reflection
Take this from someone who isn’t exactly a fan of the sappy Filipino romance film

There’s a warmth and dignity in how they’re represented

Sure, the film softens some of the grittier truths about working in the care sector, but there’s still enough nuance here
it gives well-deserved visibility to women ofws in mainstream ph cinema

Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards, troopers of this Pinoy rom-com industry, churn out career-best performances held by their own individual wits and charms, and not by whatever makes this weird fish-out-of-water-out-of-country plot ticks, which at times does seem to be some oddly manipulative crushing/stalking maneuvers on Ethan's behalf

But as an immigration/emigration story goes, "Hello, Love Goodbye" weaves around its complexities more deftly than most - love overcomes displacement, but it doesn't vanquish it, even in the most heart-stricken princess stories
Leave to pursue your dreams, or stay for the love of your life
This is the question that Hello, Love, Goodbye asks us
This latest offering from Cathy Garcia-Molina, best known for her Filipino romantic comedies, is set in Hong Kong
Molina sheds light on the experiences of Filipinos working overseas by following the story of Joy and Ethan, two Overseas Filipino Workers (OFWs)
We see their lives unfold through the eyes of Joy, a hardworking domestic helper who’s trying to save money to move to Canada as a nurse, and Ethan, a bartender trying to find his motivation in life
Hello, Love, Goodbye stars two of the Philippines’ biggest names from the two of the biggest “loveteams”—Kathryn Bernardo (from KathNiel) and Alden Richards (from AlDub)
What’s also surprising is that Bernado and Richards are from rival television networks; in the Philippines, it’s common for actors to be signed to one network exclusively
Their performance in Hello, Love, Goodbye proves that once in a while, it doesn’t hurt to break out of your loveteam to grow as an artist
In Hello Love, Goodbye, Bernado graduates from her teen roles and blossoms into a dramatic actress—a total transformation from her child acting days—in a tour de force performance
Richards rises to the challenge and exhibits his versatility as an actor, proving why he’s one of the country’s matinee idols
To get into their roles, Bernardo was separated from the cast to better empathize with Joy’s feelings of isolation; after just a week of filming in Hong Kong, she wanted to go back to the Philippines
Richards, on the other hand, lost almost 25 kg to play Ethan
Molina is notorious for her strictness with the artists that she works with—but it’s paid off as they are all household names, and her films have been blockbuster hits
Hello, Love, Goodbye’s story is not new, yet it provides us with a unique perspective of the realities of being an overseas worker
The film tears away the layers of the OFW experience with sheer intensity
Shifting away from showing the employee-employer relationship found in other films about OFWs, Molina brings her focus to the OFWs themselves, and their families back home

Hello, Love, Goodbye is the film that is sure to be successful
It stars actors that has a huge fan base and the storyline is centered on love
I didn’t think much of it at first and expects it to be just another hugot film
Especially, Cathy Garcia-Molina was directing it
One More Chance 2019, I feel like
But, it’s different
One, the setting was in Hong Kong
The film made sure to maximize their time abroad by shooting in different locations
Also, they highlighted it in a way that the scenes are almost always outside
The team guaranteed that once the movie is seen, the audiences will be transported to Hong Kong as well
Second, aside from love, the movie dwells on the topic of work
How OFW’S work themselves to the bone and how they survive on a day-to-day basis
Kakai Bautista’s role was the most impactful for me as an OFW
She might not have as much lines at Kathryn Bernardo’s but when she says it, it rings true
Lastly, the feministic principles of Joy, the heroine
There might be a trend of feministic heroines on Cinema lately like Nadine Lustre’s on Never Not Love You but it still is special
The way Joy was written was phenomenal
The dialogue was on-point, the justification is there and the way the character grew was understandable
Her decision especially on the Climax point of the movie hurt but it is inevitable
Her line of how the emptiness inside her will never be filled by romantic love alone was poignant
Overall, the movie is great as it arises discussion amongst its viewers

The Story of the film depicts the life of a breadwinner modern world which is joy, struggling over dream, love, and passion that she have
These problems are common to be the obstacles of those who has the responsibility of taking part in raising a family where the parents are both unable to
In the film, joy has always been determined to help her family out of poverty that she forgot to live her life according to what she needs and what she wants
When tested by the time and love, she has no choice but to let go of her personal desires and pursue the goal that she has set for the future of a better life with her beloved parents and siblings

My professor in Introduction to Global Society class in DLSU just used this film to discuss migration

Here are some of the points we talked about after viewing the film:- Migration has become less of a choice but a necessity- There are different types of migration, such as labor (for work) and marriage, as shown in the film- Migration is driven by economic factors- There is a cost/benefit analysis whenever someone migrates- OFWs are perceived as “well off” just because they are in another country- Underemployment is common
Better to be underemployed in another country than in the Philippines
- There is a certain identity maintained by the Filipino diaspora; there is always a hope to come back homeNay, may uwi po akong broccoli at pansit

Hello, Love, Goodbye catapulted itself as not only the highest grossing Filipino film of 2019, but also of all-time
Unlike previous title-holders, this acclaim is well-deserved because the film is actually good
Two overseas Filipino workers (OFW), Joy and Ethan, meet in Hong Kong and fall in love
However, Joy is planning to leave the city soon to pursue her dreams elsewhere
Meanwhile, Ethan is about to become a permanent resident and is at the cusp of building a long-term life there
What’s most notable about Hello, Love, Goodbye is how it immerses us into the OFW experience — the daily hustle, the homesickness, and the impermanence of it all
Not that the story is any different from Anak or Sunday Beauty Queen, but the film managed to go deep into the lives of domestic helpers and Hong Kong residents with so much authenticity and breadth
And then there’s the pairing of Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards, which propels the film’s dramatic stakes to even greater heights
Both are completely believable not only as lovers, but also as people trying to make their families proud

The film’s overarching theme of “chasing after your own ambition” will surely resonate with everyone — that being in a relationship doesn’t mean that you have the same goals in life and that ambition is a personal thing
Every once in a while, we get a Star Cinema film that breaks out of the rom-com mold and superficial happy endings
I am absolutely floored with how the film ended
Even more so that they didn’t attempt to reverse the “goodbye” with an “after 10 years” epilogue
Being a Filipino working overseas feels suffocating, which this film manages to execute that feeling perfectly thanks to the performances of Kathryn Bernando and Alden Richards
The reason why people love this film wasn't because of the romantic moments between Bernando and Richards, but because of how the film depicted the unglamorous life of an OFW

After bringing more misses than hits, it's safe to say that HELLO, LOVE, GOODBYE is the film that finally gets Cathy Garcia-Molina back on her feet to once again captivate the Pinoy cinephile's attention thoroughly

As a celebrated contributor to modern Philippine cinema with her iconic Star Cinema features from previous years, she seems to have lost her touch with her being inclined on quantity-over-quality style of releasing films

2018's 'The How's of Us' which starred Daniel Padilla and Kathryn Bernardo may have worked for some, but to others, it all still felt trite and stale as that still felt like a star vehicle than a supposedly enthralling story-centric piece about young romance

Molina must've listened to the critics because her 2019 offering is quite special for a lot of things ––– all of which make it a solid venture into new horizons for the filmmaker that hopefully, she'll continue to explore to continue an exciting streak of films potentially started by this one
If one were to take it a step further, it's also a bold film, really for what it shows and tells to the audience as a mainstream release that makes it slightly unconventional and powerful
What makes it so is the strength of the discourse that astonishingly, marvelously overpowers that of the Star Cinema rom-drama formula that Molina has always gripped onto

It seems to have came at an opportune time, too, considering the state of Hong Kong during the time of its release which makes it a film of considerable significance that brings enlightenment to a wide audience about the OFW experience overseas
The film can work and be enjoyed both ways, and that's really where the magic can be found, tasted, and adored

As a social commentary piece about the lives of OFWs in Hong Kong, it's fascinating and moving specially because of how the characters of Joy and Ethan are written with specificity where the drama is stressed and is made impactful
And so, that brings us to the other side of the film that makes the romance that they try to invigorate worth buying into knowing their stories that can pretty much be anyone's
Looking deeper into those two facets of the film, it seems like everything here works fine and well, and indeed it does that it feels like a charm so unbelievable in how it is conceived

Though the film may still fall under the trappings of Cathy Garcia-Molina's films, such as the sappiness of the romance or the movie-like dialogue that takes away an amount of authenticity, they aren't huge hindrances to the film being well-formed

Molina doesn't merely make it all feel like a star vehicle for Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards after all since there's meat given to the characters they play courtesy of co-writers, Carmi Raymundo and Rona Co
It may be unexpected, but believe it or not, the screenplay of the film is astonishingly rich even if the direction isn't as masterful as one would like it to be
The actors really work from that, bringing great stuff for us to commend, absorb, and feel; almost Even with the flaws resting in it, there's no way for one to not be won over by what this film packs

A love letter to OFWs not only in Hong Kong, but all over the world who sacrifice themselves for love in different ways, it rightfully deserves to be seen and embraced as a new classic for the memorability of how it converses, which shows its profound dedication and respect to those it represent onscreen with immense accuracy

It's honestly the kind of Star Cinema film that you'd hope to be made more often; tempered, substantial, and resonant ––– a film that knows how to reach its audience in ways that don't feel too compromised and feeble in their attempts
Sobrang buong-buo ung character ni Joy at natuwa ako na nabigyan ng highlight din ang struggle ng atin mga kababayan na nagpapakahirap sa ibang bansa

isang nakakatuwa at nakakalungkot na pelikula na nakabalot sa isang klasik cliche filipino rom com na tungkol sa buhay ng mga ofw natin na nakabase sa hongkong may magandang mensahe at mga tema na maayos na nailahad simple lang ang istorya girl meets boy tas boy keeps disturbing the girl even if she blatantly rejects him already mejo hindi ko lang natripan yung ilan sa mga katangian sa karater ni alden richards pero overall tingin ko nabawi naman natuto naman siya sa hule at saludo ako sa ending dahil yun ang siyang nararapat at maganda ang sinasabi dito na sa tunay na buhay e hindi magiging perpekto ang lahat at hindi palaging happy ending pero ang pagtanggap natin sa riyalidad na ito ang siyang tama at makabubuti sa atinmahusay na inilarawan dito ang mga pinagdadaanan ng ating mga modernong bayani sa araw araw nila maski sa hirap sa trabaho ginhawa sa piling ng kapwa nila pilipino pagsuko gawa ng lungkot pagsisisi sa mga maling desisyon, pagsasakripisyo nilang dulot ng pagmamahal at sa hindi nawawalang simpleng kaligayahan ng mga pinoyhindi ko alam kung okay ba saken yung pagiging madalas na pagtaglish ng dayalog, siguro mas gusto ko lang na purong pilipino kasi nga pelikulang pilipino to pero dahil ganun din ako madalas magsalita dulot ng kasanayan e madali ko naman tinanggap tsaka nasa ibang bansa sila normal naman na ganon, mas magustuhan ko lang ng konte siguro kung pinanindigan yung pagkapilipino sa ganung pamamaraan

magaling ang pagarte ng mga bida lalo na sa mga eksenang dramatik ayos din na ramdam na ramdam ang kemistri nilang dalawa may ilang istorya lang na hindi masyadong nabigyan ng tuon at hindi nabigyan ng magandang konklusyon tingin ko dapat mas binawasan yung mga romantic scenes kapalit ng mga yon pero sino ba naman ako para magsalita tingin ko lang naman yon ang titulo nga naman ng pelikula e hello, love, goodbye alam ko naman kung ano pinasok ko sa pagnuod netosa pangkalahatan e sobrang enjoy naman tingin ko ang pinakapuso ng pelikula ay nasa kanilang mga pamilya at sekondarya lamang ang kanilang pagibigan, isang kwento na karapatdapat na naisapelikula at karapatdapat na maibahagi at mapanood ng marami at yun nga ang nangyaribest moments para saken e yung mga solid na comic relief ng mga side karakters tulad nung mga linyang mader packer ako yung manager dat sakin ka nagpapaalam stuckroom at marami pang iba

This is a story that hits close to home because of my mom
I don’t know the details of what my mom went through working also as a domestic helper in Hong Kong
What i do remember though is something she said in passing; that she would cry every night because she was away from me
I never thought of my mom leaving me in the Philippines when i was younger as something easy
I knew it was hard, i just didn’t know HOW hard
I respect and love my mom so much and knew she did a lot for me but this film made me see things differently

That respect and love blinded me, it never crossed my mind to really think about what she went through and now to think that she did all of that for me fills me with emotions i can’t even begin to explain
I’m so thankful but also so sorry
I just hope i’m able to repay even just half of what she has given me and she has and continues to give me everything
I read somewhere once that flying makes you more prone to crying but I think that even at ground-level, this movie would have made me cry
On the surface, it looks like your typical Filipino romcom

Guy meets girl, one of them dislikes the other initially, the other person is interested and tries to win their affection by being both pabebe yet persistent, a montage ensues, and as much as one party tries to fight it, they eventually fall in love (chAr)
I remember seeing the trailer for this sometime last year and wanting to watch it because it looked promising

While the movie does fall trap to some of the cheesiness and tropes (read: Ethan's backstory) that make the aforementioned typical local romcom weak, it manages to bring a depth to its characters, including l Hong Kong itself, that usually escapes mainstream blockbusters
This is exemplified in Joy's character
I've been a Kathryn Bernardo fan since grade school (hello Mara Clara) but this is probably her best performance to date
We are thrown headfirst into the demands of Joy's life and her routine, the pacing of which I really enjoyed
Duty to family, the dichotomy between practicality and passion, and the price of following your dreams take on a new meaning in her situation
You can't help but root for her and (if you're like me) want to throw a shoe at Ethan
The movie never outright asks you for sympathy
Instead, it paints an honest picture of things as they are for so many OFWs in Hong Kong
It leaves the viewer instead to decide how they feel about not just the characters' situations, but also the very systems that birth and perpetuate them
Glad I was finally able to catch it
I didn't manage to finish the whole thing but am hoping to during quarantine
After seeing Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards with other screen partners for so long, who would have thought that they too could ooze out an undeniable chemistry
I admire both of their performance in this film and I really hope they'll have more projects in the future
Hmm, sounds like "Three Words from Forever"

Straightforward as this title is, whatever the complications and heartbreak in Cathy Garcia-Molina's latest romantic tragedy, they can't be any heavier than the story that has to be behind Kathryn Bernardo not playing opposite Daniel Padilla
No, I'm sure their marriage is as annoyingly adorable as ever, especially since this film doesn't set a good tone for them seeing other people, onscreen alone

Bernardo plays a free-spirited domestic worker in Hong Kong, with a diverse network of friends that - don't worry, Filipino conservatives upset about an onscreen couple not being married offscreen - isn't too diverse
She naturally hits it off with a handsome fellow Philippines expat, an ambitious bartender looking to lay some roots down in the city our woman can't wait to get the heck out of

As the two begin to look to their seemingly temporary friendship to help them weather the Hong Kong hustle, it becomes clearer that they have ideas to spend their lives together, and extremely different ideas about how to
As the title plainly tells you, this story won't work out, but it is charming, way to a fault
I mean, this is clearly just another trite and sappy romantic-comedy-drama, of little consequence and even less surprise, with a runtime of two hours
This doesn't want to be "just another", as it lives up to its title by methodically examining the process of a potentially doomed romance with the intimacy and draw of a prestige love story
There's more potential on paper than you'd think, but of course it's all hijacked by overwrought rom-com sensibilities, especially with bouncy pacing and gratingly corny, relentless music
Jessie Q
Lasaten's score sucks, and it's just about omnipresent throughout an authentically paced drama to bring out the inauthenticity of its melodramatic situations, frilly farce and general genericism
The script doesn't help with its quirky sense of humor and hearty or histrionic breakthroughs, all cheapening substance that is just full enough to water down that punch-up
That script may only feel obligated to pander to the lowest common denominator, but it sits between the tritest of romantic melodramedies and the most cloying of aesthetics
The average rom-com viewer may also get bored with the runtime, so of course I find more compelling than the average rom-com
There's certainly a unique enough romance in the gorgeous, ever-bustling backdrop of Hong Kong explored extensively as its own character
This scope is more than enough to liven up this intimate love story
but just to be safe, let's overshoot the environment, overwork the editors, and overplay an oppressively corny score

There's nothing refreshing or challenging about this shameless fluff piece, but its themes are a little more grown-up than usual, more frank about the chore of reconciling romantic interests with personal ones

Histories of failures and potentials for success are heavily debated and approached in this two-hour dual-character study, at a methodical clip that may bore certain viewers without the fallback of zanily colorful supporting characters
They bring some laughs, and texture the personalities of lead characters who are spoiled by their own, more mundane humor and quite a few humiliatingly cheesy bearings of soul

Besides that, their motivations and relationship turns are thoroughly, even complexly drawn, and tightened under the solid chops and crisp chemistry of the beautiful Kathryn Bernardo and the handsome Alden Richards
This takes the time to build a genuine human drama, but it's squandered on meager fluff

Between the ready-made claptrap and the meanderingly thoughtful romantic dual-character study, the former pretty much prevails on grating music, style, comedy and melodrama, with enough entertaining sprawl in the lavish Hong Kong setting, more colorful characters and endearing flair, and enough real nuance in the characters, their relationship and the performances, to make Cathy Garcia-Molina's "Hello, Love, Goodbye" a touchingly heartfelt, just as abrasively disingenuous romantic melodramedy
75/5 - Fair

Anyway, the film's brilliance isn't about Joy and Ethan's romantic relationship
It's how the film showed, using the perspective of Joy, the plight of the OFWs in Hongkong
It stripped the usual Hongkong image as a vacation destination by using the DH life montage as a background
We need more of this kind to let us understand more how the Filipino diaspora is a socio-political issue we need to address
How the "bagong bayani" suffers, not just from homesickness, but from social inequities

Alden Richards - it’s my first time watching him in a full-length anything
He works in a TV network that I hate, so I’ve never really seen him act that much
Anyway, I’ve been trying to figure out what’s different about his face
He’s handsome, for sure; but I just couldn’t put a finger on that one thing that’s different until I saw him in this movie
I know it now — he has a very shallow, barely there philtrum
Maybe from the years of wearing braces, his upper lip flattened out
Anyway, Kathryn was good

But then Alden spoke, so there

With unrelenting chemistry and superb acting from its two leads, "Hello, Love, Goodbye" turns out to be an outstanding romance drama film experience

Against the backdrop and introspective of our country's modern day heroes, the OFWs (Overseas Filipino Workers) specifically domestic helpers in Hong Kong, the film was able to bank on even more emotions than expected
Life in Hong Kong is not easy more so for the domestic helpers who are unable to improve their lives even if they wanted to
One of these domestic helpers is Joy (Kathryn Bernardo) who has wants to leave Hong Kong and find a better life in Canada as a nurse
But unfortunate circumstances have prevented her from attaining this life-long dream
Ethan (Alden Richards) is a bartender and has a few years left before he can be a permanent resident in Hong Kong
Both meet one fateful night and while they do not fall instantly in love, Ethan's persistence eventually wins Joy's heart
But their polar opposite circumstances and dreams will make the decision to continue with their relationship a difficult one to make
"Hello, Love, Goodbye" does enough to make it one of the better romance drama films we have seen
How it accomplishes this is by pretty much making outstanding work on the basics
First and foremost, the central characters of Ethan and Joy were well-written and well-scripted
Both characters had deep-seeded personal issues that were not only central to the film's main conflict but grounded and believable
The script was mostly great having its fair share of emotional one-liners and witty banters but we have to admit, it went a little too cheesy in some scenes
Beyond that, both characters had great actors and performances behind them that gave these characters much life and much justice
Additionally, the main narrative was well-written
It felt fresh and had a lot of unexpected twists, turns, and surprises along the way
The ending was satisfying without spoiling much
It also presented a basic look into the stark reality of the OFW domestic helpers in Hong Kong
However, we felt that the film failed to establish more emotions on this introspective
While it had some unnerving revelations about the domestic helper life, most of these have been tackled better in other films previously
What surprised us most though if the film's cinematography
It's a given that Hong Kong is a beautiful city to begin with but the camera work here impressed us
Overall, "Hello, Love, Goodbye" is a great romance drama film worth your time and one heck of a dramatic film at its core

For a Star Cinema fare, the best thing this film does is to finally not force a happy ending to please its target audience
That was my biggest issue with Cathy-Grace Molina’s previous film, The Hows of Us — resolving all conflicts in order to reach a happy ending that feels fake

Make no mistake, this film is also boggled down by the same trite and cheesy writing (Making Kath’s and Alden’s character an official couple is so forced), overblown musical score, and emotionally manipulative sequences that have plagued the quality of Star Cinema films for the past few years
However, this film is effective as a drama that talks about Filipino Diaspora
It even takes away the usually bright gloss aesthetic of a Star Cinema film; which I loved
There’s a sense of realism at play
It shines at moments when it doesn’t delve on the romance, but on the struggles faced by Filipinos working abroad
When we are shown how these Filipinos find ways to cope up and form a stronger bond as a community of overseas workers — the film is at its most human
Past its flaws, the film is something I appreciated
It’s a semi-fresh take that is just a bit uneven

**Watched this for class, and we talked about the rift between mainstream and independent cinema in the Philippines

**The opening sequence of Hello, Love, Goodbye (2019) is almost exactly the same as the first few minutes of Sid & Aya: Not a Love Story (2018), as it makes use of a montage of the scenes to come, all while Joy (Kathryn Bernardo) describes Hong Kong, and her life, and how she perceives love

Again, similarly with Sid & Aya, the first part only follows Joy as she lives her life as a domestic helper, then it pulls the "then it all changed" cliché when Ethan (Alden Richards) comes in and pulls out some weird and cringe-y pick up lines to woo her (And funny enough, just like Sid & Aya, the woman has little to no interest in the man)
This film almost masquerades as the usual mainstream Filipino romance, with its structure and overall production
It has invisible editing, clear visuals, and an upfront and chronological structure (with exception to the first flash forward montage and a few flashbacks)
But where Hello, Love, Goodbye diverts from the "usual" is in the complexity of its characters' struggles as its plot progresses
Joy is "lost potential," with the film implying that she was an excellent college graduate
She is almost drowning in responsibilities as a domestic helper, but continues to hustle harder and harder to provide for her family, and to keep her fading dreams alive
Ethan is a hotshot bartender who is secretly full of regret, as he previously left his whole life behind just to chase a girl he desperately loved
Joy and Ethan's dynamic starts out weird, but their love reluctantly grows as Joy comes closer to her dreams and as Ethan slowly comes to terms with his past
Towards the end, as Joy and Ethan are arguing about their future, and what love means to them

Alden Richards and Kathryn Bernardo's performances are strong and passionate in the later acts (despite some very mushy lines here and there), and perhaps this is where the artistry of the independent film lies
Their performances and their lines are the things I pondered about long after the credits rolled
This film definitely leans more towards the mainstream cinema
The mainstream elements significantly outweigh its "indie" elements
But, it has a certain depth and profoundness in the messages it delivers to its audience thanks to its good writing and performances

It's far from a perfect film, or a film that I would consider a modern classic, but I can definitely see this being enjoyed by a lot of different filmgoers with different tastes, as it does have a little something for everyone
And because of all these, it's clear to see why this is currently the highest grossing film produced in the Philippines

"The time stops when you don't use it
" There's a single aspect in Hello, Love, Goodbye that makes it truly worth watching—its fairly authentic portrayal of the collective plights of Overseas Filipino Workers (OFW)
As a former OFW's kid, this one definitely hits home, and it's pretty much the same feeling I had when I watched Sunday Beauty Queen
I have heard a lot of stories about their struggles abroad including from my mom and dad
The moment Joy (Kathryn Bernardo) shouted "I love you all pero 'tangina, pa'no naman ako
" was pretty reminiscent to that of my mom's sentiments about her experience when she was feeling down while at work
It's really sad, and this one spoke so much to me
And so, I'm gonna give this film a point for that
However, other than the things mentioned earlier, everything ranges from being dull to borderline decent
I have to commend Bernardo's very emotional portrayal of a very emotional character
She eventually ended up carrying the entire film, while Alden Richards, despite being constantly labeled among fans and critics for slightly stepping up his game, seemed a little stale
The chemistry was there, but it didn't really hold up in the long run
I also have to acknowledge how problematic the start of their romance was
See it for yourself then

Moreover, the film still succumbs to clichéd tropes we usually encounter in Filipino romantic films, not to mention the terrible use of music just to evoke emotions that would only work for, dare I say it, wild fans
It's nothing new, so I had to endure it
Hello, Love, Goodbye would have been a huge knockout had it been focusing on Joy's story arc
It's the only thing in the film that I was fully invested in
How it treated the romance aspect was decent at best, but its establishment damaged the film tremendously
Gosh, it could have been so much better, really

Like on one level it makes some sense: it’s about two attractive young people who meet and fall in love in an exotic locale, and they’re played by two huge movie stars
Pretty easy to see how that gets butts in the seat
It’s so bleak
Their lives are so unpleasant

Both are Overseas Filipino Workers stuck in immigration traps in Hong Kong, forced to submit to exploitation in order to retain proper status (one especially tragic scene has a Filipino who's working as a nanny beg her employer to keep her on at half pay because losing the job means getting deported back to the Philippines
and this is a college-educated worker with dreams of being a nurse)

Our heroine’s mother gets beaten by her (foreign) husband whom she despises, but has to stay with him for another few months to become a resident (and then the rest of her family--who were left behind in the Philippines--can join her)
The driving force of the movie is essentially how these punitive immigration rules ruin their chance at true love and happiness
It’s a necessary (and timely) topic, and it’s handled with great care, but

A surprisingly affecting romantic drama about the large community of Filipino domestic workers in Hong Kong

This is something that has been recently explored as a more heart warming drama with Oliver Siu Kuen Chan and Anthony Wong's excellent Still Human, however here we have a similar situation but shown almost entirely from the Filipino workers perspective and with a significant romantic plot

Through central character Joy, who wants to be a nurse, but is forced into the domestic helper lifestyle like her mother, it looks at the difficulties and exploitation inherent in these worker's arrangements

Paid a pittance, and treated appallingly by their employers and the state, this film examines how they can be trapped into this existence and life, allowing them to send a bit of money home to family in the Philippines that they only speak to via video calls, promising a reunion that will never happen
There's an excellent movie in here, but the film stumbles significantly when introducing Joy's love interest, barman Ethan
While it may appear like this film is going to be a standard romantic comedy, it's not really, and Ethan's initial characterisation is straight out of a lunatic American rom-com
After being introduced by pretending to be immigration police and arresting Joy, he's harassing and calling her constantly, that even within the constraints of a romantic comedy (which this isn't
), he's basically a stalker

It's a shame that the film goes down this initial cliched route, after introducing Ethan's character for the next twenty minutes, because at it's core, and once Ethan stops behaving like a lunatic, it's a genuinely tender and quite tragic film about a doomed romance, and about how Filipino immigrants to Hong Kong are never made to feel part of society

The films portrayal of both Ethan's father and Joy's parents is well done, and very sympathetic, which makes it more frustrating that they wasted so much time with Ethan's initial character, when they could have skipped that and presented him as he appears for the last hour of the film

It's filmed on the streets and alleys of Hong Kong, and all extremely recognisable and vivid, clearly made by someone who understands the areas, full of classic "oh yeah, I know where they are" moments
Surprisingly bittersweet ending too
This is mostly an excellent film, that's dragged down unnecessarily by the initial appearance of Ethan - made even more frustrating that they roll that characterisation back
Still, definitely worth my time, and a lot better than I expected (but it could have been just that bit better)

5/10For me, it’s a very typical Pinoy romance you’d expect from Star Cinema, so I won’t really go into the quality and narrative of the film
What always fascinated me was how this stands as the highest grossing film of all time in the Philippines
Having an OFW-centred story would definitely play a huge role in this benchmark, since the OFW struggle is a very real experience among working class Filipinos
There’s a whole history behind OFW films that I’d love to look into further while I’m still studying Honours
It was also jarring to have watched this after seeing two Wong Kar Wai films these past few days — I say this because this film is set in Hong Kong
So for me, it felt like an interesting exercise in comparing both localised and transcultural portrayals of a country

I don’t really have a right to comment on the way Cathy portrays Hong Kong people, or whether or not this captures an “authentic” Hong Kong experience outside the OFW life, but this is also something I’d like to scrutinise more closely
I think I can get behind why people would see this as above average, and despite it being an average experience for me, I appreciate the film for what it is
I would love to write further about the film’s OFW narrative and transcultural elements, as they are both integral to shaping Philippine cinema as a globalised medium
(PS: watching Kathryn Bernardo sing badly has been the most cathartic thing I’ve seen all year)

Cathy Garcia-Molina departs from rom-coms in a touching tale of sacrifice and love in a city far from home
Leave to pursue your dreams, or stay for the love of your life
This is the question that Hello, Love, Goodbye asks us
This latest offering from Cathy Garcia-Molina, best known for her Filipino romantic comedies, is set in Hong Kong
Molina sheds light on the experiences of Filipinos working overseas by following the story of Joy and Ethan, two Overseas Filipino Workers (OFWs)
We see their lives unfold through the eyes of Joy, a hardworking domestic helper who’s trying to save money to move to Canada as a nurse, and Ethan, a bartender trying to find his motivation in life
Hello, Love, Goodbye stars two of the Philippines’ biggest names from the two of the biggest “loveteams”—Kathryn Bernardo (from KathNiel) and Alden Richards (from AlDub)
What’s also surprising is that Bernado and Richards are from rival television networks; in the Philippines, it’s common for actors to be signed to one network exclusively
Their performance in Hello, Love, Goodbye proves that once in a while, it doesn’t hurt to break out of your loveteam to grow as an artist

An Empathetic, Authentic PerformanceIn Hello Love, Goodbye, Bernado graduates from her teen roles and blossoms into a dramatic actress—a total transformation from her child acting days—in a tour de force performance
Richards rises to the challenge and exhibits his versatility as an actor, proving why he’s one of the country’s matinee idols
To get into their roles, Bernardo was separated from the cast to better empathize with Joy’s feelings of isolation; after just a week of filming in Hong Kong, she wanted to go back to the Philippines
Richards, on the other hand, lost almost 25 kg to play Ethan
Molina is notorious for her strictness with the artists that she works with—but it’s paid off as they are all household names, and her films have been blockbuster hits
Hello, Love, Goodbye’s love story is not new, yet it provides us with a unique perspective of the realities of being an overseas worker
The film tears away the layers of the OFW experience with sheer intensity
Shifting away from showing the employee-employer relationship found in other films about OFWs, Molina brings her focus to the OFWs themselves, and their families back home
The film strips down the glamor of Hong Kong, as we follow Joy waking up at 5am every day, hustling through the crowded streets of Hong Kong—away from her family, never catching a dream
She sits down on top of cardboard boxes on Sundays in Central and juggles taking care of her employer’s daughter and grandmother while selling power banks as a side job (which is actually illegal)
Molina blends drama and clarity in portraying these hardships, and most importantly, tells the “whys
”The Burden of Responsibility“If you stop, you’ll starve”—that’s the reason why
Joy, and thousands of other OFWs, endure these hardships to provide for their family back home—a message that the film strongly reinforces

We watch as Joy’s friend reminds her cousin to be smart with her money so she can have enough to send back to the Philippines, as the same friend tells her father that she’ll stay two more years because they need the money
Domestic helpers only earn as little as HK$4,520 (US$576) per month, while working long hours
In Joy’s words, if you stop working, your family will starve
Making sacrifices is almost always a given—a harsh reality if you’re an OFW because you have a responsibility to your family back home
This responsibility that Joy carries is one that resonates with many other OFWs
But OFWs carry out this responsibility at what expense
Similar to Still Human, which also featured a Filipino domestic helper, Joy has a degree in nursing
In fact, nursing is a common degree among Filipinos with the hope of working overseas for better pay than what they can get back home
As it turns out, nursing is actually the dream that Joy wants to pursue, and being a domestic helper is just a stepping stone to that goal
Then Ethan comes into the picture
While a movie following the plight of domestic helpers and OFWs doesn’t really need a romance story, the love story still has a purpose
Ethan’s character contrasts with Joy’s
While Joy is hardworking, determined, and knows what she wants in life, Ethan is a happy-go-lucky guy who jumps from one relationship to the next and doesn’t know what he wants in life
But his character’s free-wheeling life also echoes Joy’s self-questioning of whether choosing ourselves over our family makes us a disappointment, or selfish
Joy laments the lack of choice she has in life
As the family’s breadwinner, her family doesn’t know what she has to endure on a daily basis
A nursing graduate that cleans the toilet and eats leftover food—“I’m more than this job, I’m more, and I want to be more,” Joy says
Surely, this sentiment reflects the many dreams of other overseas Filipino workers
They have dreams but they also have responsibilities that hold them back
Joy and Ethan’s romance show the heavy burdens and choices OFWs face on a daily basis
Even something as minor as buying a snack or not is difficult, because every dollar spent is a dollar you could have saved to give back to your family
Dreams vs
LoveA common Filipino phrase, “libre lang mangarap,” tells us “it’s free to dream”
But Joy and Ethan realize, as they try to make their love work, that dreams aren’t free
When you make a choice, you give up something
Joy and Ethan’s mutual romance story mirrors the same sentiments that their individual stories have: choices, responsibilities, and dreams
Perhaps that’s the reason why the romance element works against the backdrop of an OFW story
In this sense, Hello, Love, Goodbye isn’t just a love story, nor is it just an OFW story—it’s a story about finding yourself, and loving yourself in the process
This universal message is something that will strike a chord with audiences
Hello, Love, Goodbye‘s message is simple: give yourself the chance to do what you want, get back up from disappointments, be courageous enough to love and choose whether you want to leave or stay

The film doesn’t portray Bernardo and Alden as people to pity—it portrays them as human beings, with stories and experiences that empower them to ultimately choose how to pave their own way for their futures—with or without each other

I found it a bit cluttered and tedious in the first half but it gets better, more focused and complex after the male protagonist’s family situation is revealed
Even then, I felt most of the time we were being kept at arms’ length from the characters; close, intimate shots were so rarely used

I like its very mature approach to relationships, though, and by echoing the ending of the sparer, more eloquent Endo, it illuminated the ending of that movie for me, showing that by not pursuing his love before she’s ready, the guy is showing commitment and hope, a willingness to wait
It showed his character had grown, also it’s something anyone who wants to get somewhere in life needs these days, so it’s good that Filipino films are promoting this value

KATHRYN BERNARDO ATE AND LEFT NO CRUMBS
Finally, I watched the highest grossing Filipino movie of all time as well
Hello, Love, Goodbye was on my list since it’s official release
With the new pairing I took some time to get into the mood
All my Filipino friends confirmed to me that the portrayal OFWs is indeed a very accurate one
It was indeed frustrating to watch the everyday struggle and hard work of educated young people in minor jobs to support their family
Nowadays it belongs to the normality to support their families through migration
It’s indeed a very depressing atmosphere and all the problems and concerns were well portrayed by Katheryn Bernardo in this movie
She did an amazing job as usual
But this time the melodramatic vibe really flashed me
Same for Alden Richards
I have to admit that I had my doubts to see Katheryn in a movie without Daniel but all my concerns were for nothing
The whole superstar casting and the successful capture of the OFWs situation makes this movie captivating
I really enjoyed the realistic view and the reality that hits the viewer in every scene
The survival and emotional struggle is detailed pictured and I really loved it that the characters stay true to themselves, no matter how hard is life
To be honest, the depressing reality clash were indeed very much needed and an eye opener for a foreign audience
The movie promises nothing and stays true to itself like it’s main protagonists
